question_text: A student believes an unknown compound is a carboxylic acid. IR and ¹H NMR spectroscopy are used to confirm its identity.

orders.text_content:
a) What two key features in the IR spectrum would support the identification of a carboxylic acid?
(2 marks)

solution.solution_text:
\[
\text{A broad peak at 2500–3300 cm}^{-1}\text{ from the O–H stretch.} \\
\text{A strong peak at around 1710 cm}^{-1}\text{ due to the C=O stretch.}
\]

orders.text_content:
b) The ¹H NMR spectrum shows a singlet at 11.5 ppm. What does this signal represent?
(1 mark)

c) The molecular formula of the compound is C₂H₄O₂. Propose a structure and justify it based on the spectra.
(2 marks)

solution.solution_text:
\[
\text{C}_2\text{H}_4\text{O}_2 with IR and NMR data supports ethanoic acid (CH}_3\text{COOH).} \\
\text{IR: broad OH + carbonyl; NMR: singlet at 11.5 ppm and methyl protons near 2 ppm.}
\]

question_text: A compound with molecular formula C₃H₆O is suspected to be either propan-1-ol or propanone. IR and ¹H NMR spectroscopy are used to determine which it is.

orders.text_content:
a) What key difference in the IR spectra would help distinguish propan-1-ol from propanone?
(2 marks)

solution.solution_text:
\[
\text{Propan-1-ol shows a broad O–H stretch around 3300 cm}^{-1}. \\
\text{Propanone shows a strong sharp C=O peak around 1715 cm}^{-1}, but no broad O–H stretch.}
\]

orders.text_content:
b) The ¹H NMR spectrum of the compound shows a singlet at 2.1 ppm and no signals above 4 ppm. Which compound does this suggest and why?
(2 marks)

solution.solution_text:
\[
\text{Singlet at 2.1 ppm is consistent with the CH}_3\text{ groups on either side of a carbonyl in propanone.} \\
\text{Absence of peaks above 4 ppm indicates no O–H group, confirming propanone.}
\]

orders.text_content:
c) Name one way mass spectrometry could also distinguish between propan-1-ol and propanone.
(1 mark)

question_text: A compound with molecular formula C₄H₈ was suspected to be an alkene. IR and ¹H NMR spectroscopy were used to confirm the identity.

orders.text_content:
a) What feature in the IR spectrum would support the presence of an alkene?
(1 mark)

b) The ¹H NMR spectrum shows two doublets at 5.5 and 6.0 ppm and a singlet at 1.8 ppm. What does this suggest?
(2 marks)

solution.solution_text:
\[
\text{Doublets at 5.5–6.0 ppm indicate vinylic protons on a C=C bond.} \\
\text{Singlet at 1.8 ppm likely corresponds to CH}_3\text{ groups near the double bond.} \\
\text{Consistent with but-2-ene.}
\]

orders.text_content:
c) Could mass spectrometry confirm the molecular formula? If so, how?
(1 mark)

question_text: A compound with molecular formula C₆H₆ was analysed using IR and ¹H NMR spectroscopy. The results are shown below.

orders.text_content:
a) What feature in the IR spectrum would suggest the presence of an aromatic ring?
(1 mark)

b) The ¹H NMR spectrum shows a single peak around 7.3 ppm. What does this suggest?
(1 mark)

c) If the molecular ion peak in the mass spectrum is at m/z = 78, what does this confirm?
(1 mark)

question_text: A compound with molecular formula C₃H₈O was analysed using ¹H NMR. The spectrum showed a triplet, a quartet, and a broad singlet. Use this data to answer the following questions.

orders.text_content:
a) What does the triplet suggest about the type of hydrogen environment?
(1 mark)

b) What does the quartet indicate?
(1 mark)

c) The broad singlet appears around 2–5 ppm. What type of hydrogen does this represent?
(1 mark)

d) Suggest the identity of the compound based on these signals.
(1 mark)

question_text: A chemist uses HPLC to analyse a mixture of three compounds. The HPLC chromatogram shows peaks at retention times of 1.2, 3.8, and 7.6 minutes.

orders.text_content:
a) What does a retention time represent in HPLC?
(1 mark)

b) Which peak corresponds to the least strongly retained compound?
(1 mark)

c) How could changing the polarity of the mobile phase affect retention times?
(1 mark)

question_text: A compound with molecular formula C₂H₆O was analysed using mass spectrometry. The spectrum showed a molecular ion peak at m/z = 46 and a base peak at m/z = 31.

orders.text_content:
a) What does the peak at m/z = 46 represent?
(1 mark)

b) What does the base peak at m/z = 31 suggest?
(1 mark)

c) How can mass spectrometry help distinguish ethanol from dimethyl ether (also C₂H₆O)?
(2 marks)

solution.solution_text:
\[
\text{Although both have m/z = 46 for their molecular ion, their fragmentation patterns differ.} \\
\text{Ethanol shows m/z = 31 (CH}_2\text{OH}^+), while dimethyl ether may show m/z = 45 or 29.}
\]
